comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Their book, "Modern Dancing," appeared in 1914. Vernon Blythe adopted Castle as a stage name. Irene's maiden name, appropriately, was Foote. Here is a short film clip of Irene, from 1914: www.britishpathe.com/record.php?id=77119 And from You Tube, Vernon and Irene dancing together: www.youtube.com/watch?v=j5TE74e9vAg

comment.author: 62233671@N03
comment._content: Thanks Wystan. I saw Waldo, but I thought he was a fur collar. Oops!

comment.author: 67876522@N02
comment._content: “Wolf”, the Alsatian, was a relative of Rin Tin Tin, another World War One battlefield survivor. A tongue-in-cheek photo feature in the Perrysburg Journal (Ohio), published June 14, 1917, tells his story: “German ‘Traitor’ Dog is Vernon Castle’s War Prize.” “Vernon Castle’s ‘German traitor’ dog has been the object of keen admiration among friends of the actor since his return to America from the battlefields of France, where he has been doing service with the British Flying Corps. The dog is of the breed used by the Huns for police work and also for Red Cross scout duty. It was originally in the German army, but, being, an especially intelligent animal and vigorously opposed to murderous Kaiserism, it boldly deserted to the English forces in the thick of battle. Now the dog is thoroughly British, so much so that he dotes on making mincemeat of any dachshund he can find. The picture is the first which Mrs. Vernon Castle has had taken with her husband since he came home.” chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn87076843/1917-06-14/ed-...

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Marv, that's a wonderful story, thanks. Incidentally Susan Orlean (author of "The Orchid Thief") has a new book out, about Rin Tin Tin, the original dog star of the movies, who was discovered as a German Shepherd pup in a nest of newborn puppies in the middle of a WWI battlefield, surrounded by the disasters of war. Susan was interviewed this morning (9/24/2011) on NPR.

comment.author: 67876522@N02
comment._content:
Thanks, Wystan.  I read the review of Susan Orlean's Rin Tin Tin book in the New Yorker a few weeks ago.  His master's divorce from a woman who just couldn't compete with him for her husband's affection put me in mind of the joke: "I got a dog for my husband. It was a really good trade!"

At present, I'm immersed to my eyeballs in early 20th century show business history, in hot pursuit of something called "the collie ballet," in which the father of my first wife appeared in 1910 (she died in 1991, and her father, Walter Burke, died in 1966, too soon for me to have met him).  Both the ballet and Mr. Burke were minor features of a smashingly successful musical called "The Top o' th' World," which launched him on a thirty-year theater and vaudeville career.  The wonderful Dolly Sisters' routine, "The Dollys and their collies," was a pale imitation of this act presented many years later.  Walter also happened to be a WWI pilot who was in training in Texas at the same time, or just after, Vernon Castle crashed and died there on a training flight in 1918.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: If the January, 1914 on the negative is correct, though, the story of the "German Traitor Dog" would seem to be made up by the press or Vernon C's management, since war didn't break out until August, 1914. It's possible that Irene is holding her pet monkey in her right hand, as she is in this other Bain photo:

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: I think I figured this out. The 1917 German Shepherd was a different dog. Vernon Castle started a kennel at his country home in Manhasset, NY, and had acquired a pedigreed German Shepherd to show and make available for stud. "TELL MAY BE IN PERIL. Dancers are in France With Their German Shepherd Dog, Vernon Castle, who is now abroad, took the German shepherd dog Tell von Flugelrade with him. The more than ordinarily high trained dog cost Mr. Castle $1,000, that price being paid to L. I. De Winter of the Wlntervlew Kennels at the Long Island Kennel Club show at Sheepshead Bay for the imported son of Frank von Flugelrade and Irma von Flugelrade. Mr. and Mrs. Castle went to France, where they expected to exhibit their dog." N.Y. Sun, 8/26/14 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1914-08-16/ed-... This German Shepherd is probably Tell. The scratched out caption about Wolf and Wallop might be from a mistaken later entry on the 1914 negative. "Wallop" is pictured as one of Mrs. Castle's prize-winning[ Brussels Griffon] in a June, 1915 picture: www.corbisimages.com/stock-photo/rights-managed/U28059INP...
